A subgroup of a group is normal if and only if it is closed under conjugation by elements of the group.

type:
∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H K : Subgroup G},
  H ≤ K → ((H.subgroupOf K).Normal ↔ ∀ (h k : G), h ∈ H → k ∈ K → k * h * k⁻¹ ∈ H)
name: Subgroup.normal_subgroupOf_iff
docString: A subgroup of a group is normal if and only if it is closed under conjugation by elements of the group.

This theorem states that for a given additive subgroup of a linear ordered additive commutative group, if this subgroup is disjoint with the open interval from 0 to a positive number `a`, then this subgroup is a cyclic subgroup. In other words, there exists an element `b` such that this subgroup can be generated by recursively adding `b` to itself, expressed as `AddSubgroup.closure {b}` in Lean. This theorem holds under the condition that the underlying group is Archimedean, which is a property implying, among other things, that given any two positive group elements, there exists a positive integer multiple of the smaller element that exceeds the larger element.

type:
∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup G] [inst_1 : Archimedean G] {H : AddSubgroup G} {a : G},
  0 < a → Disjoint (↑H) (Set.Ioo 0 a) → ∃ b, H = AddSubgroup.closure {b}
name: AddSubgroup.cyclic_of_isolated_zero
docString: This theorem states that for a given additive subgroup of a linear ordered additive commutative group, if this subgroup is disjoint with the open interval from 0 to a positive number `a`, then this subgroup is a cyclic subgroup. In other words, there exists an element `b` such that this subgroup can be generated by recursively adding `b` to itself, expressed as `AddSubgroup.closure {b}` in Lean. This theorem holds under the condition that the underlying group is Archimedean, which is a property implying, among other things, that given any two positive group elements, there exists a positive integer multiple of the smaller element that exceeds the larger element.

A finite subgroup of the unit group of an integral domain is cyclic.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {G : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Finite G]
  (f : G →* R), Function.Injective ⇑f → IsCyclic G
name: isCyclic_of_subgroup_isDomain
docString: A finite subgroup of the unit group of an integral domain is cyclic.

In a group, if a subgroup is normal, then its elements are closed under conjugation.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H : Subgroup G}, H.Normal → ∀ n ∈ H, ∀ (g : G), g * n * g⁻¹ ∈ H
name: Subgroup.Normal.conj_mem
docString: In a group, if a subgroup is normal, then its elements are closed under conjugation.

This theorem states that every subgroup of integers (`ℤ`) is cyclic. More specifically, it asserts that for every subgroup `H` of the integers, there exists an integer `a` such that `H` is the subgroup generated by `{a}`. This means that every element of `H` can be written as a sum or difference of copies of `a`, which is the formal definition of a cyclic group in group theory.

name: Int.subgroup_cyclic
docString: This theorem states that every subgroup of integers (`ℤ`) is cyclic. More specifically, it asserts that for every subgroup `H` of the integers, there exists an integer `a` such that `H` is the subgroup generated by `{a}`. This means that every element of `H` can be written as a sum or difference of copies of `a`, which is the formal definition of a cyclic group in group theory.

A non-cyclic multiplicative group is non-trivial.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Group α], ¬IsCyclic α → Nontrivial α
name: Nontrivial.of_not_isCyclic
docString: A non-cyclic multiplicative group is non-trivial.

In a simple group, every normal subgroup is either the trivial subgroup or the entire group.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [self : IsSimpleGroup G] (H : Subgroup G), H.Normal → H = ⊥ ∨ H = ⊤
name: IsSimpleGroup.eq_bot_or_eq_top_of_normal
docString: In a simple group, every normal subgroup is either the trivial subgroup or the entire group.

This theorem states that in any multiplicative group of a certain type `α`, if the group is not cyclic, then it must be nontrivial. Here, `Nontrivial α` means the group contains at least two distinct elements, and `IsCyclic α` means the group is generated by a single element. In other words, a non-cyclic group cannot be a trivial group (a group with only one element).

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Group α], ¬IsCyclic α → Nontrivial α
name: Nontrivial.of_not_isCyclic
docString: This theorem states that in any multiplicative group of a certain type `α`, if the group is not cyclic, then it must be nontrivial. Here, `Nontrivial α` means the group contains at least two distinct elements, and `IsCyclic α` means the group is generated by a single element. In other words, a non-cyclic group cannot be a trivial group (a group with only one element).

A finite group of prime order is cyclic.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Group α] [inst_1 : Fintype α] {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], Fintype.card α = p → IsCyclic α
name: isCyclic_of_prime_card
docString: A finite group of prime order is cyclic.

In a simple group, every normal subgroup is either the trivial group or the entire group.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : IsSimpleGroup G] {H : Subgroup G}, H.Normal → H = ⊥ ∨ H = ⊤
name: Subgroup.Normal.eq_bot_or_eq_top
docString: In a simple group, every normal subgroup is either the trivial group or the entire group.

This theorem states that for any given type `G` which forms an additive group, the subgroup generated by multiples of any element `g` of the group (denoted by `AddSubgroup.zmultiples g`) is equivalent to the closure of the set containing just the element `g` (denoted by `AddSubgroup.closure {g}`). In other words, the cyclic subgroup generated by `g` is the smallest subgroup of `G` that contains `g`.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] (g : G), AddSubgroup.zmultiples g = AddSubgroup.closure {g}
name: AddSubgroup.zmultiples_eq_closure
docString: This theorem states that for any given type `G` which forms an additive group, the subgroup generated by multiples of any element `g` of the group (denoted by `AddSubgroup.zmultiples g`) is equivalent to the closure of the set containing just the element `g` (denoted by `AddSubgroup.closure {g}`). In other words, the cyclic subgroup generated by `g` is the smallest subgroup of `G` that contains `g`.

A finite subgroup of the units of an integral domain is cyclic.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] (S : Subgroup Rˣ) [inst_2 : Finite ↥S], IsCyclic ↥S
name: subgroup_units_cyclic
docString: A finite subgroup of the units of an integral domain is cyclic.

type: {G : Type u_1} → [inst : Group G] → (H : Subgroup G) → [h : Subgroup.IsCommutative H] → CommGroup ↥H
name: Subgroup.IsCommutative.commGroup

type: ∀ (K : Type u_1) [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : NumberField K], IsCyclic ↥(NumberField.Units.torsion K)

A group is commutative if the quotient by the center is cyclic.

type:
{G : Type u_1} →
  {H : Type u_2} →
    [inst : Group G] →
      [inst_1 : Group H] → [inst_2 : IsCyclic H] → (f : G →* H) → MonoidHom.ker f ≤ Subgroup.center G → CommGroup G
name: commGroupOfCycleCenterQuotient
docString: A group is commutative if the quotient by the center is cyclic.
